Because getting feedback and buy-in from stakeholders is crucial for project success.

To engage the audience and clearly communicate the value of your idea.
To make stakeholders understand and support your project, possibly with funding or feedback.
With a question that addresses a problem from the customer's perspective.

text: A clear request for money, feedback, or advertisement support.
It clearly answers the problem statement and functions smoothly.
Some initial content to showcase during stakeholder interaction.
Because stakeholders have limited time and expect to see real results.

The concept, the running product, the process, and the next steps.

Prepare their own pitch and demo for stakeholder feedback.

Sprint 5 is focused on preparing a demo of your project for stakeholders, where you show progress and get feedback.
At minimum, your instructors. But ideally, real or potential users, mentors, or anyone who could benefit from or evaluate your project.

) presents the demo to the stakeholders.
Yes, kind of. A pitch is a short, persuasive talk (2–5 minutes) where you explain your idea, why it matters, and what you need.

Yes, you can use slides. Keep them minimal and clear. The focus is on what you say.

It means your solution changes the way people normally do things — like a big improvement or new approach.
It's the task or need your user wants to solve. You're showing that your product helps them get that job done better.
That's the grading scale — 0 means missing, 1 is partial, and 2 means well done. Each demo component is scored like that.
Usually group grades, but sometimes instructors adjust based on individual contributions.
Yes, but you need to show at least some working part or simulate it. Be honest and explain your progress.
It means your demo should be interactive — let them click buttons, explore your app, etc., even if limited.
Yes, online presentations are allowed if arranged in advance.
Check the schedule in your course materials — usually at the end of Sprint 5.
Yes, stakeholders and instructors will give you feedback right after your presentation or in writing later.
It's a graph showing slow growth at first, then fast growth later — like a hockey stick curve.
Yes, just a basic version — how you think the product could earn money or bring value.
That's okay — describe your target users and how you plan to reach them.
They're often presented together: first the pitch (2–5 min), then the live demo (5–10 min).
Yes! Ask your instructor or check the course platform — many past examples are available to review.
Absolutely — that's encouraged! Ask your TA, mentor, or instructor to review your draft.
Ideally, yes — covering the problem, solution, market, team, business case, insight, and ask shows a complete picture.

qas.question: What if we don't have any "unique insight

text: Try to think about what you've learned during development or from your users — even a small insight is valuable.

qas.question: How do we make our pitch "fun

text: Use a personal story, humor, or surprising fact — just make sure it still fits the message and stays clear.

qas.question: Is it okay to say "we're not sure yet

text: Yes — honesty is appreciated if you follow it up with what you're doing to figure it out.
Yes, if you do not have enough data, you can skip the market graph. Just make sure to explain this in your presentation.

Definitely rehearse both — especially transitions and any technical parts that might break.
Both are important, but the demo often speaks louder — it shows what you've actually built.

qas.question: What are we supposed to do during the "Teams formation

text: You're expected to form your project team and choose a topic or direction to work on.

From March 14 until May 16, 2025.

Falling behind can affect your group grade, so it's important to stay on track — speak to your TA if issues come up.
These are planned dates for 2025 — major shifts are unlikely but possible in exceptional cases.

Yes, a widely used structure is the Problem–Solution–Why Now–Market–Team–Ask framework. It helps you clearly present your idea by addressing the problem you're solving, your solution, why it's timely, the market opportunity, your team's strengths, and what you're seeking from your audience.
Absolutely! The
approach emphasizes storytelling, emotional connection, and clarity. Focus on a compelling narrative, use relatable examples, and keep your message concise and impactful.
Follow the
principle. Ensure each slide conveys a single, clear idea. Use visuals and minimal text to keep your audience focused and engaged.
Yes, Guy Kawasaki's 10/20/30 Rule suggests using 10 slides, delivering your presentation in 20 minutes, and using a minimum 30-point font size to maintain readability and clarity.

You can find resources online by searching for the specific frameworks. For example, look up articles and videos on the Problem–Solution–Why Now–Market–Team–Ask structure, TED Talk presentation techniques, the One Slide, One Message principle, and Guy Kawasaki's 10/20/30 Rule.

Yes, there are several popular methods to structure a pitch. For example:
* The Problem–Solution–Why Now–Market–Team–Ask framework (great for startups)
* The TED Talk style, which uses storytelling and emotion
The One Slide, One Message principle (helps make your slides clear and focused)
* The 10/20/30 Rule by Guy Kawasaki (10 slides, 20 minutes, 30 pt font)

You can choose the one that suits your style best — or combine them! Let me know if you want a quick explanation of any of these.

Start by thinking of a simple story: what problem are you solving and how? Then build around that using one of the common structures like the Problem–Solution–Ask method. Don't worry about slides at first — just try to explain your idea clearly in 1–2 minutes.
No, there's no single
method — use whatever helps you tell your story clearly and confidently. That's what really matters.
A demo is a short, practical presentation of your product or prototype — you show how it works, what it solves, and why it's useful.
A pitch is more about telling the story behind your idea, while a demo is about showing it — you let people see or interact with the actual thing you've built.
Yes! Many demos follow a

:
   1. Start with a problem
   2. Show how a user would solve it with your product
   3. Highlight the best or most unique part
   4. End with a result or next step

Some also use the
method: show something impressive right away to grab attention.
A good demo is short, clear, and reliable. It tells a story, avoids bugs, and makes people go,
That's okay — you can show a part that works, use mockups, or even show a screen recording. Just be honest and explain what you've built so far.
It's best to talk while showing — explain what you're doing and why. Think of it as giving a short guided tour of your project.

Sure! Here's a simple plan:
      1. Pick one user problem
      2. Show how your product solves it
Practice clicking through that flow
      3. Time yourself — aim for 2–3 minutes

Add your voice and you've got a demo!
Yes — you can use tools like Loom (for screen recording), Figma (for UI mockups), or live browser setups. But sometimes even just a working webpage and good narration are enough.
Avoid trying to show too much, relying on unstable code, or reading from a script word-for-word. Also avoid rushing — go slow and clear.

A great place to start is the Y Combinator Demo Day. Startups pitch their ideas in just 2 minutes — concise, clear, and often very impressive. You can find recordings of Demo Days on YouTube and study how they communicate their value fast.
Check out the TechCrunch Disrupt Startup Battlefield. Startups present live demos to expert panels — it's a great way to see how real products are introduced under pressure.
Yes! Companies like Figma, Notion, and Stripe are famous for clean, user-focused demos. They often show exactly how their product fits into real workflows — simple but powerful.

Yes — look at IDEO and Stanford d.school. They teach how to use storytelling, design thinking, and empathy in presentations. Their materials and case studies are publicly available and incredibly helpful.
Definitely! Many of the best presenters use storytelling, show a clear
transformation, and build tension around the problem. Guy Kawasaki's presentations are also a masterclass in clarity and brevity.
Yes, it's completely normal — even experienced speakers get nervous. A bit of adrenaline can actually help you focus. The key is to prepare and practice so you feel more in control.
Try deep breathing, stretching, or even a short walk. Some people use power poses or mindfulness techniques. Avoid caffeine right before your presentation.
Don't panic. Take a pause, breathe, and try to continue from the last thing you remember. You can also keep a small note with keywords to guide you — it's totally okay.
It's better to practice until you can speak naturally. Reading from a script can sound robotic and lose the audience. Try to memorize the flow, not the exact words.
Be honest. Say something like,
It's better than guessing. You're not expected to know everything.
Practice speaking out loud beforehand, breathe deeply before you begin, and focus on your message, not on yourself. Confidence grows with repetition.
Absolutely. Nerves mean you care. The audience won't notice your fear as much as you think — they're rooting for you more than judging you.
You can delegate, but it's a great learning opportunity. Even saying one part or introducing your team can build confidence over time. Try to push yourself a bit.
If humor feels natural to you — yes! But don't force it. A warm smile and speaking with genuine energy often works better than a rehearsed joke.
Just acknowledge it calmly and move on. Most people won't notice small errors — what matters is how you continue.
Focus on clear, simple language. Practice with a friend or record yourself. The goal isn't perfect grammar — it's communication. Your message is more important than perfect words.
Practice out loud — alone, in front of a mirror, or with a friend. Record yourself and watch it back. Repetition builds comfort and flow.
That's okay. You're not presenting perfection — you're showing progress and ideas. Focus on what you've learned and built. Confidence comes from owning your work, not from having all the answers.
Not at all — the pitch can be shared. One person can open, another can explain the solution, and someone else can close. Just make sure the flow is smooth and everyone knows their part.
Think about each person's strengths. Who's confident speaking? Who knows the tech side best? Assign parts based on comfort and expertise — and support each other.
That might work if the rest agree, but this is a team project. Everyone should be involved at least a little — it shows collaboration and shared effort.
Not necessarily. The best demo presenter is someone who can explain things clearly, not just the one who built it. You can help each other rehearse.
Yes! One person can do the pitch, and another can lead the demo. Just make sure the transition is smooth and clear.
Choose 1–2 speakers for the main parts and let others take smaller sections or Q&A. It's better to have a strong, focused delivery than squeeze in everyone.
Yes, that's smart. Decide who answers which types of questions — tech, design, user side, etc. That way, you won't stumble or talk over each other.
They can still help by managing the slides, running the demo, or supporting during Q&A. Even a short intro line can help them feel included.
Practice the full flow together. Agree on cues for when each person speaks. Think of it like a mini theater play — rehearsals make a huge difference.
Pause and talk it through calmly. Focus on what's best for the project, not personal ego. You can even test different versions and vote — or split roles fairly.
Yes, slides help guide your audience and support your message — just keep them clean, simple, and not overloaded with text.
Around 8–10 slides is usually enough. You can follow the 10/20/30 Rule: 10 slides, 20 minutes max, 30-point font or bigger.
Each slide should focus on one idea: problem, solution, market, team, demo preview, etc. Use titles that clearly guide the audience.
Using a clean, modern template is totally fine — it saves time and keeps things consistent. Just make sure it fits your project's tone.
Only if they're subtle and purposeful. Avoid flashy effects that distract from your message.
Use screenshots, diagrams, icons, or mockups — anything that helps explain your idea visually. People remember images better than text.
Bullet points or short phrases work best. You should speak the full explanation — don't put everything on the slide.
Only if it's important for your audience to understand the value. If not, skip or move it to Q&A or appendix slides.
Yes, and it's often safer! Just make sure the video is short, clear, and well timed with your narration.
Google Slides, PowerPoint, Canva, or Keynote — all work great. Choose what's easy and lets you collaborate with your team.
No — focus on the most important feature that best demonstrates your value. Quality over quantity. Too much can confuse or overwhelm your audience.
Ask yourself: what's the core of our idea? What makes it special? Build the pitch around that. Leave extra details for Q&A.
Only if it's critical to understanding your value. Most of the time, high-level explanation is enough. Save deep tech talk for technical Q&A.
No, instead show how the overall experience is better. Use one example to represent the improvement, not a checklist.
Create a clear demo script or outline. Rehearse it several times. Prioritize showing one full flow rather than jumping around features.
Yes! Think of the user's journey: problem → using your solution → result. That helps keep the flow focused and relatable.
Usually going deeper into one key feature is more impactful — it shows depth, not just breadth.
Yes, briefly — in the
or
part. Just don't dwell on them or apologize for what's missing.
Consider showing a prototype, mockup, or video. If it's unstable live, it's better to simulate than risk a crash during the demo.
Yes! Guide their attention — say things like
or

It shows you're engaged and respectful.
Take a breath and speak slowly. You know your project — trust that. It's better to speak simply and clearly than to try to sound perfect.
Yes! Before the presentation, decide who handles tech, user, business, or design questions. It avoids awkward silence or overlap.
Just smile and quickly defer —
It happens — what matters is how you recover and stay coordinated.
